text: What I try to do is I try to derive a specific forecast for realized volatility and for implied. Like it does not have to be perfect, but I wanna have, to me it's always better to have an opinion and having a forecast than to not have one and just systematically do something. And so what I'll do is if my forecast is let's say for implied volatility to hold steady and or spike, then what I'll do is I'll take that forecast and I'll say, okay, what is the most efficient way to express this forecast? What product and what trade structure will give me the biggest bang for my buck? Cause I'm all about getting paid when you're right. That's one of the things that over the years I've managed to make a good acquaintance with a lot of sort of professional institutional volatilizers and that's one of the things that you always shouldn't talk about. Get paid when you're right. Don't mess around and accept pennies on the dollar when you actually forecasted something, correct? And so that's what I'll do. So for example, in the volatility space, if I think that implied may hold steady or spike, then I'll go to the ETPs and then I'll look at, okay, is there a VRP inside of the ETPs? So like right now it's March 15th, 2021, in at least the way I measure it, there's a pretty strong risk premium in the options on the ETPs. So you see a lot of people come in cause I think a lot of institutional people wanna express the VRP in a risk defined way. So they're buying puts like crazy across the ETP space and in the VIX space. And so someone like me looks at that and I say, well, you know what? This is potentially a time where I can maybe sell a put, hedge the Delta with the cause. And I think that those puts are inflated and I'll be able to make that margin. But it's all about the forecast and then finding the most efficient structure to give me the best bang for my buck.
